statement.p: Graph the equation \displaystyle{y}={3}{\left({5}^{{-{x}+{1}}}\right)}+{5}. You will select a point on the asymptote (only y coordinate matters); then you select two points on the exponential.

solution.p: Because \displaystyle{y}={3}{\left({5}^{{-{x}+{1}}}\right)}+{5} has \displaystyle+{5} at the end, the asymptote is at \displaystyle{y}={5}.
One convenient point is where \displaystyle-{x}+{1}={0} which is \displaystyle{x}={1}. Here \displaystyle{y}={8}.
A second convenient point is one left of 1, which is \displaystyle{x}={0}. Here \displaystyle{y}={20}
